answers.author: [Unknown]
answers.text:
Hello,
There was a similar question asked not long ago:
http://icma.org/en/icma/knowledge_network/questions/kn/Question/22351/JointlyContracted_Maintenance_services__Research
Although the question was focused on maintenance services, the real issue is partnership.  Many cities are experimenting with partnerships to reduce costs in many areas.  I think these are a few resources linked in the above question that might interest you most:
Two municipalities found a way to split water distribution costs by building a joint water tank. It's some pretty cool technology:
http://icma.org/en/icma/knowledge_network/documents/kn/Document/304203/Dual_Core_Storage_Tanks
The MPI (Municipal Partnering Initiative) is a large collective of local governments working together on projects.  Organizations can choose to opt out, so the partnership keeps organizations investing only where they will benefit:
http://icma.org/en/icma/knowledge_network/documents/kn/Document/304199/Municipal_Partnering_Initiative__Glenview_IL_Lake_Forest_IL
You can check the partnerships topic for more information on local government partnerships:
http://icma.org/en/icma/knowledge_network/topics/kn/Topic/194/Partnerships
I hope you find some of this information helpful!
Gabe Brehm
Knowledge Network Intern
ICMA

author: [Anonymous]
text:
Hello all,
I am interested in obtaining any information you may have on creating a joint public works venture between two cities. Have any of you done this or seen it happen in a successful way? Has your city administration discussed merging public works facilities with another city, and what resources have you found helpful? 
Thanks in advance,
title: Information on joint Public Works venture?
